pros: Good team members Progression opportunities

review_title: Toxic Environment of Bullying and Harassment from Management
pros: Lovely, passionate, and supportive team of employment facilitators who really care about the young people they support
cons:
Toxic work culture - the company really needs to reevaluate their management teams, especially in Glasgow. Management bully and harass employees and staff turnover is extremely high as a result. Multiple complaints have been made about management and have been repeatedly ignored including several official grievances. Higher ups often show little interest or care for employees who come to them regarding concerns about harassment and bullying. 

Low salaries for roles that are sometimes akin to that of a qualified social worker.

Poor training regarding introducing new employees to AFC’s recording database, etc

Obsessed with meeting targets with little to no flexibility regarding this. Feels very corporate as a result and there is an additional responsibility on staff to recruit more young people for their caseloads to meet said targets. Feels more like a sales role in a lot of ways and distracts from the good work employees do to actually support the young people already on their caseload.

pros: The kids give you a reason to show up every day
cons: The management team are focused on power and control, happy to create fear and watch employees suffer

pros: Fantastic mission to support vulnerable children. Frontline services do great work.
cons: No career development or training. No manager accountability. Poor communication between teams and within teams. Wasteful in terms of resources.

job_title: Senior Family Support Practitioner in Wellingborough, England
pros: From day one of moving from the Local Authority, into working for Action for Children the difference was noticed immediately. Much emphasis was placed on staff safety and welfare (something which I had not experienced before!) - a mobile phone was given, we had to detail which homes we were visiting and an approximate finish time so the admin staff knew when we should call in by. If no call was received then the admin staff acted on this immediately. My work always received high praise and appreciation (again, this is something which frequently went unnoticed by LA) Monthly supervision sessions really did take place monthly (or sooner if requested) and feedback questions were always followed up and responded to. Regular Team Days took place so that all of the cluster centre staff could meet up too.
cons: Undergoing restructure and pay awards pending. The moulding of the new services ongoing, since local LA budget cuts is uncertain - which causes nervousness amongst the staff who fear for their jobs (permanent staff)

review_title: What an amazing job I have
